key_behaviors: Uses AI to improve writing (grammar, cohesiveness) for case studies
Uses AI to create executive summaries of longer documents
Asks AI specific questions, e.g., to define steps in a process for research
Relies on AI to speed up content polishing and summarization
pain_points: Too many UI icons and features make the tool feel overwhelming
Understanding all available features requires a training tutorial that users don’t have time for
Uncertainty about the exact prompts needed to get desired results
Potentially intrusive integrations (e.g., AI reading email to create calendar entries) are unwanted
trust_factors: Rates trust in AI results as high (4/5)
Believes AI speeds up the writing and summarization process
Feels AI provides “a nice job of summarizing key information”
desires: An assistant that initiates a guided conversation, asking “What are you here for today?” and then probes for deeper needs
Context‑aware prompting that helps users formulate effective queries
Simplified, discoverable UI that reduces the need for tutorials

verbatim_quotes.quote: I generally use AI to improve my writing. Lately, I've been writing case studies, so I'll use it to help enhance the grammar and cohesiveness of some of the statements that I put together.
It speeds up the process of ensuring that the statements sound good and make sense.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Perceived value of AI in writing

verbatim_quotes.quote: I also use it to create summaries. For instance, I might take an entire case study worth of work and create an executive summary, and it does a nice job of summarizing key information.
I have used it to ask specific questions as well. For example, I might ask it to define steps in a certain process for research or something like that.

I think I've been pretty happy with what I've used ChatGPT for in the past. However, an ideal assistant maybe would prompt through questions, like asking, "What are you here for today?" Then, it could listen to your answer and ask probing questions to get to what you're really looking for.
What would be helpful is that you don't always know the exact prompts that ChatGPT or other AI tools need to be successful.
Sometimes, the amount of different features in the tools can be overwhelming, so having guidance would be very helpful.

For example, in Insider, for chat, there are lists of icons down the side and on the top. They're all over. In order to really understand what's fully available, you would need to take a training tutorial, I think, and people don't have time for that.
I'm sure AI could look at my email and then create calendar entries, things like that, but that would be too intrusive and not something I would be interested in.

I think it went pretty well. I actually work in user research and I'm familiar with in-person interviews and moderated interviews. I liked that it took into account the person's responses and then modified probing questions afterward.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Positive perception of AI interview adaptability

verbatim_quotes.quote: However, it's difficult to ever replace the one-on-one interaction with an actual human, but I think this does a pretty good job.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Limitation of AI vs. human interaction

verbatim_quotes.quote: Face-to-face interaction with an actual human is hard to replace, as well as the nuances of being able to understand people's emotions and follow up on that.
I don't see how it would be possible for an AI interviewer to understand emotions.

unique_insights: The participant, a professional user researcher, reports no major failures with ChatGPT yet expresses a strong desire for a conversational, guided prompting experience that reduces the cognitive load of figuring out prompts and navigating a cluttered UI. They value speed and quality in writing and summarization, trust the tool highly, but remain skeptical about AI’s ability to grasp emotional nuance, highlighting a clear boundary between functional assistance and human‑level empathy.
